reviewText: Richard Basehart missed the boat this time as awful Adolph.A better version is 1944 The Hitler Gang,Robert Watson is much better as the deviant nazi dictator.From his days at the close of WW1 to his power rise due to double crossing and murders.Roman Bohnen is especially good as brown shirt chief Ernest Rohm.Martin Kosleck repeats his role as Goebells.Narrated by Walter Abel and Albert Dekker.Dir by Hohn Farrow.

reviewText: 1962 U.S. film (later re-released as "Women of Nazi Germany"). It starred Richard Basehart as Hitler. The film depicts Hitler through the years, beginning with the 1923 "Beer Hall Putsch" in Munich. It focuses mainly on his private life, in particular, his relationships with niece Geli and longtime mistress (later in April 1945, his wife for less than 2 days), Eva Braun. Simply, a low budget, fictionalized account with many inaccuracies.It is still not as bad as the 1973 British TV production, "The Death of Adolf Hitler", which I would rate the worst. Thereafter, the presentations of Hitler got better in a factual sense. Next in line, after the subject film, from worst to best would be: "Hitler: The Last Ten Days", which is almost a parody of the facts, as well. Then would come the HBO production "The Bunker", with Sir Anthony Hopkins. The best and most accurate film to date on the subject is the German feature film, "Downfall" (A/K/A Der Untergang). See my reviews of all of these films.
summary: Bad, but not the worst of the biographical films on Hitler...
Title: N/A

reviewText: HITLER (a/k/a "Women of Nazi Germany", U.S. release, 1962) with Richard Basehart as the evil dictator. Having reviewedThe Misfits, dating from the year before, this is almost a relief. Problem is, this thing is a set-stage piece; Basehart deserved a true, full-blown film budget for his brilliant, weird portrayal of Hitler. And bear in mind that this wasn't something people were jumping to play. It might have been a career-killing move.Hence the "Freudian" take on Hitler attempting to make the moves on his niece (Marie Emo). Yes, Hitler had a niece (his sister's daughter) and he was very fond of her. Good enough, lights, camera, action, print it!! In fact, Basehart's greasy evil villainy aside, this film has nothing of note, nothing of interest to a WWII or history buff. It shows a silly portrayal of a man too obsessed with his niece to be of much use. If Hitler had really been this way, the world would have been saved.I recommend it for the creep factor and some of the things about Hitler they accidentally got right. Mainly I like it because I can understand it, why they did this at the time they did. And certainly one can see exactly why the great Basehart was chosen to do it. After all, too, this was based on very accurate facts: Hitler did have a sister very close to him. His nephew, Patrick, would later go first to England then later to America to wage a campaign against his uncle. And as I have said, he was extremely fond of his niece.It is no surprise to see this is not out on DVD - at least not here. With the endless Hitler-themed films proliferating steadily since this weird offering, I really would not waste any time on this. The two stars I gave it are strictly for Richard Basehart's nearly unmatched, brilliant performance. He even got the tone of Hitler's voice precisely.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Richard Basehart gives a sharp, searing portrayal of Hitler--who rose to power by executing all who disagreed with him in a paranoid fear of treason, then in WWII executed all his officers who suggested he negotiate a treaty when all was lost, or because he imagined they were part of a conspiracy to murder him. His two mistresses are also featured as victims of his savage rage over being impotent or his feeling they were unequal to his mother who died when he was very young. Could break a few records for screen shootings, bombings, and hangings, so not for the faint of heart. The drawbacks of the film are that it overedits historical events, sacrificing better details about his relationships with his mistresses along with more accuracy for harsh, chair-gripping violence.

reviewText: PLOT: 1962 MOVIE WITH RICHARD BASEHART AS ADOLPH HITLER ~ HAMMY~Richard Basehart (Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea) as Adolph Hitler as Hitler made in 1962 and available on VHS only~ Basehart is VERY good but the script and cheesy sets make this a bit lack luster~ but worth the watch once~ Basehart has the rages, stiff body movement and "voice" inflections down pat~ he is good~ he deserved a better script~ This version focuses on the psychological obsessions of Hitler who has a mother fetish and was impotent so at times it drags~ but Basehart keeps is watching. JOHN BANNER is a second banana (Sargeant Schultz on Hogans Heros) is fun to watch as a die hard Nazi Hitler underling Strasser~ and always fun MARTIN KOSLECK who is nearly always "cast" as Dr. Goebbels~ from his sneaky looks he he also good~Basehart is a very underated actor but even he cannot save this one also try~ HE Walked By Night and Decision Before Dawn for two very GOOD movies and excellent Basehart performances.I GIVE THIS ONE 3 OUT OF 5 AND IT WOULD BE LOWER ONLY BASEHART IS STILL INTERESTING AND MAKES THIS WORTH THE ONE TIME WATCH~
summary: Hitler ~ Richard Basehart~ Hammy but worth watching once~
